Not as much for kids as we would of liked for breakfast but it wasn't horrible either (the chef made us a special pancake with a waffle batter). Two other things of note:1 it's BYOB. Bring your vodka and they'll give u a home made Bloody Mary mix. 2 cash only. Would come back to try more since I liked this joint.

31.description: Clocks aren't the first thing that come to mind when I think of grandmas, but this place somehow got it spot on. From my paternal grandmother's plastic yellow bumble bee clock to my maternal grandmother's loudly ticking wood clock that was always set fifteen minutes fast, there's something about the zillion clocks on the wall at Grandma J's that made me feel at home. That, and the fact that the waiter offered to refill my iced coffee for free!I got the Works, which had two poached eggs, bacon, hollandaise sauce, kale, mushrooms, and a fried (red) tomato over potato hash. It also came with a side of toast, butter, and pineapple jam. Part of me worried that this would be too many ingredients for one dish, but it somehow all worked. Even the ever-nutritious kale didn't detract from the deliciousness of the hollandaise and bacon.My brunch mates got the chicken and waffle fritters and the breakfast sandwich. I tried the fritters and they were kind of dry. I'll be back to try the French toast sticks and enjoy some BYOB mimosas.

34.description: A wonderful and creative little gem of a restaurant on the edge of one of the most beautiful parks in the city of Chicago.  Also, it is a worthwhile and short detour off of the new 606 trail.

16.description: Nice little place, had The Works and was happy with the food, very friendly waiter and cozy environment. Would definitely recommend and will be back!

13.description: Still love this place. While there was a 30-40 minute wait this morning and no room inside to wait, the hostess offered us coffee while we were outside. Not a super cold day, but chilly enough where hot coffee was appreciated. Decided to try something new today. Went with The Works and it was amazing. Poached eggs with kale, cheddar cheese, potato hash, hollandaise sauce, a tomato and bacon. I loved it and it was so filling.They've also acquired an ATM and two tables that replaced a coach and coffee table seating since my last visit.

11.description: Came on a Monday morning to avoid the long wait. Food was superb, ordered the chicken sandwich- was warned in advance  that food might take a while because everything wasted from scratch. Loved hearing that, too many places are pumping food out of the kitchen without TLC. Johnny attended to us and did a great job hosting.

39.description: Grandma J's now serves dinner Thursday through Saturday.  The food and staff are amazing.  I have been a fan of the brunch restaurant for a while but I have not taken the time write a review.  Tonight, I was dining with my family including kiddos 4 yrs old and 2.  The dinner menu is great - fried chicken, homemade pasta, trout and a bunch of other tasty dishes.  The waiter also offered a menu for the kids (pasta, hotdogs and a few other items.)  It was not overly busy so when we asked about the possibility of plain yellow mustard for our youngest, the staff left to grab some from a nearby grocery store.  How amazing is that?  I have always felt like I was lucky to have found the Humboldt Park neighborhood and make it the home for my family but Grandma J's is definitely the icing on the cake.  The staff makes you feel right at home and the food is just as great!

37.description: Ate here for the first time today after searching for a good place to eat brunch that had some unique items. Grandma Js did not disappoint at all. The staff is friendly and attentive. The space is quaint and comfortable but not too crowded given its size. And the food was fantastic. I had The Works and it was amazing. The perfect amount of food and everything came so well together. Will definitely be eating here again.

0.description: Hands down best breakfast joint in the city!  My girlfriend and I absolutely love this place.  You have to come here, especially in the summer when the patio is open.  The food is to die for... The mimosa tray will knock your socks off (has three separate types of juices to mix n fresh fruit)... And the service, along with the owner Layla, couldn't be any nicer and prompt.  Don't miss out!

38.description: Grandma J's is one of my favorite restaurants and its due to a combination of the perfectly relaxed decor, staff, and out of this world food. I've been for absolutely fantastic brunches too many times, but the dinner service is what really sold me on writing a Yelp review. The dinner service here is criminally under-attended and charmingly relaxed. Some of my absolute favorite food in the city.

51.description: I can see why people like this place, but you have to love kale, mushrooms, etc to appreciate their cooking. Everything tasted fresh and healthy, and the service was great (we were the only people there, probably because the hours were incorrect on Yelp & Google.) We filled up on pancakes and fritters before our food came. Cash only is a pain, even though there is an ATM on site. As a business owner, I get it.

27.description: I cannot believe it has taken me this long to review one of my favorite places for brunch in Chicago! Grandmas is a staple for brunch with friends, family and out of town guests.  What truly amazes me that it is consistently great! I have eaten here since it opened three years ago and it is equally amazing every time. Thank you!!!

32.description: We stood at the front for about fifteen minutes before someone came to seat us.  Sat at the table for like a half hour before someone came over.  Waited another eternity for the food to arrive.  Waited another eternity for them to take our money.  I am all for the "slow food" revolution but this was ridiculous. The deviled eggs were awesome.I got a breakfast plate called "The Works" which was a mish-mosh of breakfasty things.  It was salty beyond belief.  Sooooo much salt.  It was almost inedible but I was totally starving.  Overpriced, overrated, dirty floors, and absolutely pathetic service.  I probably wouldn't go back here.  Afterwards, we spent some time making fun of it.

54.description: What can I say here that hasn't already been said? The work that is being done in this little kitchen is among the best in the city, especially in the ever important byob brunch space.This is the kind of place that could literally charge double, and you would still be happy. But they don't, and that is the other half of the charm here. There's something just so inviting about a local joint, with real people running it, turning out top level food.Owner Layla is always there with a smile of some kind, and along with her warm staff, they make you feel more like neighbors and friends than customers.The Fried Chicken and Waffle Fritters might not only be the best brunch dish in the city, but maybe even the best fried chicken. The breakfast poutine, biscuits and well... everything else is just on point.If you want to go someplace for brunch without a side of pretentiousness, then get your ass to Grandma J's!

48.description: The chicken and waffles here are amazing! When ever my husband and I decide we want to withdrawal money for the cash only place we eat here. The service is great the food is great and there is hardly any noise. Will actually be there Saturday. My husband has had the fish and chips along with BLT. He is picky about how the fish is cooked so that is always the first item he orders. He loved it. Every once in awhile they do a burlesque show.

44.description: Our waiter Jon was great,  he held it down by himself.  We all got the chicken and waffles and it was fantastic.

24.description: This was one of the best brunches I've ever had. The chicken and waffle fritters were the definite standout.

7.description: Save for the waffle fritters, which were an unmitigated disaster of desert conditions, I'm excited to come back and hit Grandma J's again.  The biscuits and gravy, fried chicken and breakfast sammie were all great, and I didn't even think to bring champagne since this place is BYO so I had to wash it all down with water...I won't make that mistake again.  The servers are borderline too friendly; if you bring friends here from NYC, DC or other Northeast locations where being friendly is NOT normal, expect them to be shocked by the behavior of the friendly servers and staff.Very kid-friendly, right down to a host of toys and games that my 18-month-old used to keep herself busy.  Boosters and high chairs to accommodate a range of kid options.Also, one note--during my visit last weekend, there were only three parties in the restaurant when we ordered...and our food took almost 30 minutes to bring out.  The menus will warn you about this as well, but try not to come here ravenous or you will pay the price as you wait for your food to come out!  Seating here is fairly small, so I would skip bringing a group here larger than four people, especially on weekends.

49.description: I just had my first meal here. Quite delicious. I had "The Works" which is served in a bowl. It has cheesy baked potatoes topped with fried kale, bacon two eggs with hollandaise sauce, and a fried tomato. Excellent with their home made hot sauce. Super high quality ingredients. Although many of the ingredients are fried, the overall dish was not greasy.. Kind of a hangover goers dream.A very LARGE PORTION. I'll ask if I can split it next time. With tax came out to $15 ish... not inexpensive but worth it. The entire menu looks great. Breakfast and lunch only.They have a BYOB bloody mary option.. Just bring your own vodka and the remaining ingredients are 5$.

40.description: GREAT FOOD, Feels like eating in grandmas kitchen. Went for brunch.

53.description: I've been here several times and never had a problem with the food or staff. best to come on weekday or early on weekend.  save yourself the parking hunt and take the North ave bus to kedzie stop and your there.  Have a nice stroll in the park after to burn the calories...because you will get your share...especially if you take advantage the sides and byob

30.description: I've been on a food tour in Chicago the past 3 months, and the works might be the best breakfast dish I've had all Summer. Easily in the top 3. And the service was the most memorable I've had yet. John was an amazing host who makes you feel like a guest in his home. Bring your own vodka if you plan on drinking and bring cash.

46.description: Service was amazing, small room but atmosphere was fantastic.. I had "The Works" and it was phenomenal, the waffle fritters are great and the coffee was surprisingly delicious.. Over all. 10/10. Thanks again Grandma J!!!

1.description: So here's why I'm only giving two stars.  The food here is really good and fresh.  I've tried the biz and gravy, the works, the mushroom toast, and the grilled cheese.  All were very tasty and filling.  But after this morning I don't think we'll be back.  We got seated immediately and the wait staff was attentive.  It took 3 times asking for a virgin bloody mary to get it, but when it finally arrived it was really good.  First things first, the couple directly to my left got seated with water and they served her a glass of water with a piece of chewed up gum in the wrapper in the bottom of the glass. Lovely.We order right away and then sit there....and sit there....and sit there....and sit there.  In the meantime, I saw the main chef leave and saw three tables with no food whatsoever.  After about 25 minutes, the kids behind me got their french toast.  The parents were still waiting.  The table behind them, the kid had gotten their food and finished...the parents were still waiting.  The couple to the side of me had been sitting there for 15 minutes prior to when we got there(overheard their conversation)...So, they still had no food after almost 45 minutes of being there?  A dude walks in, high fives the waitstaff and the other chef (main chef still gone), sits down at the bar, and within 8 minutes has his breakfast sandwich.  Finally, the main chef comes in with a bag of cilantro about 30 minutes after us being there.  The parents behind us finally get their breakfast sandwich, the parents behind them finally get their fried chicken, the couple who's been there for 50 mins now still has no food and the couple sitting next to us who got there 10 minutes after us has their food.  Uhhhhhh, what the what????  So my husbo goes and talks to the owner and apparently the owner interrupts him mid sentence and says she's aware of what's going on.  He's like, "what's going on?"  Then she realizes she cut him off before he had said anything and then gets an attitude when he tells her about the gum situation and the food situation.  She then tells him she's been there the whole time (false...she walked in after us being there for about 20 minutes) and says its under control.  By this time, we're starving and go to Handlebar where we get seated, get our order, clean dishes, and great tasting food all within 15 minutes.  Grandma J's - I really wanted to love you but after this morning, I'm really disappointed. I don't know if it was a fluke, but it was too bad to be back.

55.description: Great place in Humbolt Park. Incentive dishes with ingredients that you'll feel good about eating.  Local farms, grass fed meats, etc. plus great offerings like kombucha drinks for a bit of a twist.  We had "the works" breakfast plate which was a mix of veggies, cheese, bacon, and poached eggs in a bowl. Home run. Very tastey and filling. We also the Chilaquiles with a poached egg. Was a little dry fore but I didn't like the flavor and the eggs were perfectly done. Not as much for kids as we would of liked for breakfast but it wasn't horrible either (the chef made us a special pancake with a waffle batter). Two other things of note:1 it's BYOB. Bring your vodka and they'll give u a home made Bloody Mary mix. 2 cash only. Would come back to try more since I liked this joint.

9.description: Small place with 2 cooks.. but food is dam GOOD. Went here on a Saturday and it was busy. Reguarless I received my food with-in 20 mins of walking in the door.. I can't stress how good this place is.. I will be back for sure..biscuits and gravy with 2 eggs.. YUMMY.. my experience here was positive. When I was here the owner (I think) was going around talking to people the best she can (remember she cooks and does other things that keeps her busy) I overheard a guy and girl tell her she is rude because she didn't talk to them.. hahaha! are you kidding me?! You go here to eat not talk to the owner, dam weirdo's. Your wife/ gf is with you, talk to her.. I looked at my wife and we laughed at them lol. Can't believe these dam kids got their butts hurt by this lol... She didn't talk to me and my wife and that's fine with us lol. But Honestly if your looking for a GREAT brunch place with decent prices and strong coffee this is your place.. if your looking for a friend or someone to talk to maybe look else where. Lol.. but like I said before, it gets busy.. so depending on times you go, you might have to wait a little bit.. the owner treats everyone like family (the best she can, with smiles and small talk)..

26.description: Fabulous! Really feels like I'm in my grandmas and the food is fabulous. I got the chicken and waffles and my friend got the French toast and the potato hash and everything was delish! And it's byob! Can't wait to come back when I'm in town again. Huge portions and totally worth the price.

25.description: Save for the waffle fritters, which were an unmitigated disaster of desert conditions, I'm excited to come back and hit Grandma J's again.  The biscuits and gravy, fried chicken and breakfast sammie were all great, and I didn't even think to bring champagne since this place is BYO so I had to wash it all down with water...I won't make that mistake again.  The servers are borderline too friendly; if you bring friends here from NYC, DC or other Northeast locations where being friendly is NOT normal, expect them to be shocked by the behavior of the friendly servers and staff.Very kid-friendly, right down to a host of toys and games that my 18-month-old used to keep herself busy.  Boosters and high chairs to accommodate a range of kid options.Also, one note--during my visit last weekend, there were only three parties in the restaurant when we ordered...and our food took almost 30 minutes to bring out.  The menus will warn you about this as well, but try not to come here ravenous or you will pay the price as you wait for your food to come out!  Seating here is fairly small, so I would skip bringing a group here larger than four people, especially on weekends.

12.description: What can I say here that hasn't already been said? The work that is being done in this little kitchen is among the best in the city, especially in the ever important byob brunch space.This is the kind of place that could literally charge double, and you would still be happy. But they don't, and that is the other half of the charm here. There's something just so inviting about a local joint, with real people running it, turning out top level food.Owner Layla is always there with a smile of some kind, and along with her warm staff, they make you feel more like neighbors and friends than customers.The Fried Chicken and Waffle Fritters might not only be the best brunch dish in the city, but maybe even the best fried chicken. The breakfast poutine, biscuits and well... everything else is just on point.If you want to go someplace for brunch without a side of pretentiousness, then get your ass to Grandma J's!

59.description: I went there a while back with the wife for lunch. Great service, a knowledgeable and polite staff, tasty burger and fun ambience, the old furniture is a nice touch. I hope they can get some promo priced items.

21.description: What a nice surprise! Excellent food with a cozy atmosphere. The servers were super friendly and instantly put a smile on my face. This is a great place to start your day. I don't to say too much and spoil the experience. Just go there and see for yourself!

17.description: Simply: good food, good service, good people, if u want to have a perfect breakfast just try this guys.

10.description: Came here twice in two days. The first time, the coffee was fantastic, the second, it tasted more of filter than of bean. In any case, the coffee is hit or miss, I've heard. The food was fantastic. My girlfriend is veganish (eats eggs and honey but nothing else animal-derived), and has celiac's; she indicated that she didn't want any dairy or gluten in her meal, and when the food arrived, there was bread and cheese included. After trying to eat the bowl she'd ordered with the cheese (she's a trooper), she gave up and sent it back, saying she couldn't eat it and not ordering anything else. A few minutes later, the chef came to our table with a newly prepared dish of marinated tomatoes and peppers, poached eggs, and french fries, and apologized for the misunderstanding (they only charged us for my meal). Made our day - very friendly, very good, very accommodating.

5.description: I can't help but to roll my eyes at the constant rumors that Grandma J's might not make it through the winter, or they'll have to close for some reason or another. I'm not sure if this is a cheap ploy to drum up publicity or what. Every time I come by, that place is packed, and it only has like, six tables. I don't know what they want! Other than the flare for drama or maybe it's self doubt (?) this is my favorite brunch place in the city. The food comes out slowly, but that's because there's a small kitchen. It's delicious. The portions are always heaping, but the food is incredible for the price. The server is always smiling and sweet, the mismatched silverware and decor adds some throwback kitsch, and their Bloody Mary's are on point.

3.description: If you don't know the owner/cook you'll be waiting a long time and we came with 2 kids

35.description: Prepare to wait (not for a table but for your food)! This is a place good for catching up with old friends, because you'll have to wait a long time for your food. Cash ONLY. Very hot inside with a lot of flies. No A/C and door open. It adds to the charm of the place. Suppose to feel like you're at Grandma's which I respect.Food:The Works: Pretty good. Fried Green Tomato Benedict: Not bad. Overall, the food wasn't bad but also not mind blowing enough for me to come back and wait an hour for. Also it's not cheap. I do respect what they're trying to do with the whole chill and enjoy your company vibe.

19.description: Arrived here at 1pm, it's now 3 (closing time) and we have yet to be served. I've been here before, and they do have great food; however the wait time after you order is inexcusable.

28.description: Love this place with all my heart. Amazing and soulful local food, charming vibes, locally owned and operated. Brunching done oh so well.

45.description: We were in the area checking out the new 606 trail and discovered this restaurant at lunch time. The atmosphere is charming, plenty to look at while you wait for your freshly cooked meal. The menu has twists on brunch favorites. So instead of eggs benedict, it is green fried tomatoes benedict. Delicious! Coffee is good and strong, and plentiful. Great find. Service was good too.

33.description: Awesome atmosphere, very welcoming and inviting staff.   We came on a Sunday for brunch amd it was a wait but the food was amazing! We had the morning sandwich and the sausage hash breakfast.   We were very impressed and will definitely be back! It's a nice place to invite a friend and reconnect while you wait!

43.description: The Works is delicious! Love the pictures of all the "grandma's" when they were young.

2.description: Heard some rumors that this place was goin to close! Thought I would sneak in a review. This here is a tiny joint, heavy on hipster soul, pleasant servers, and a weekend brunch menu that is worth the trip.Over a conversation of southern cooking you get a wonderfully spruced up Waffle House like menu. Nice balance between arteriosclerosis inducing and foodie friendly.Nice touch giving us the option to wait inside with a beverage. I can see where being so nice had cost you in overhead. I do hope they remain open and maybe revamp the menu for more work week clientele?Bonne chance, as they say!

18.description: I need to go back here again! I came on a whim and I gotta say, the service was great and the food was awesome!I got the Works which was poached eggs on top of potato hash with Swiss cheese marinated mushrooms , crispy kale, bacon and fried tomato in a bowl comes with toast, and some jam. All delicious! I also paired with some coffee (which they had to keep brewing but always fresh).It's a small place and it gets packed but it's very great! I just sat at the bar.

41.description: The best place I've ever been at humbold park and totally one of my favorites through Chicago.They have a tiny space, I think it was around 3 tables and a patio. Service was amazing - everyone was super friendly and still not annoying.They have beautiful old photos on walls.Food was awesome. Loved everything.Totally coming back.

52.description: My wife and I absolutely love this place. The food is always good and the service is fantastic. The owner rocks! We too are a mixed minority couple.

50.description: Can't wait to come back.  Went to Grandma J's on a Friday morning after picking up my cousins who were in from New Orleans at the airport.  First stop was Grandma J's since you can't bring people accustomed to New Orleans food just anywhere to eat. We decided to try out Grandma J's based on the reviews and location.  So glad we did!  Awesome service and even better food.  We had the fried pickles and deviled eggs to start.  Then I had The Works but prepared gluten free (lowers my head as I admit to being THAT person...) my husband and cousin had the chicken and waffle sliders and I cannot remember what the other dish ordered was but it was just as good.  Everyone was raving about their meal.  Well thought out dishes, strong coffee and great service.  We will be back!

4.description: This place is a 3.5 star for me. So I ordered The Works for brunch and it arrived in about 20 minutes or so.The good- the bacon was absolutely fantastic. Right texture, right flavour. The grilled tomato was also very tasty. Service was great and staff friendly. Manager was apologetic with the small quality glitch that I encountered (see below).The ok- the two poached eggs had different consistency, one was great, one was a bit overcooked. Hollandaise sauce was ok.The needs improvement- the potato hash needed were somewhat bland. But the big turnoff was pieces of greasy char showing up in the bowl. Grill wasn't properly scraped enough.Last but not least, coffee was way too flat for my taste...

6.description: Prepare to wait (not for a table but for your food)! This is a place good for catching up with old friends, because you'll have to wait a long time for your food. Cash ONLY. Very hot inside with a lot of flies. No A/C and door open. It adds to the charm of the place. Suppose to feel like you're at Grandma's which I respect.Food:The Works: Pretty good. Fried Green Tomato Benedict: Not bad. Overall, the food wasn't bad but also not mind blowing enough for me to come back and wait an hour for. Also it's not cheap. I do respect what they're trying to do with the whole chill and enjoy your company vibe.

22.description: What an awesome, quaint, eclectic little restaurant. Located across the National Guard Armory on North Ave and Kedzie this restaurant is a real gem. We popped in for breakfast and had the poached eggs on crispy kale and potato wedges. Delicious! I love the ambiance and the food matched the anticipation. It was a little pricy ($14 for an egg dish), but we didn't realize the size of the dish and could have split it. The owner was charming and we chatted a little about her inspiration for decor. She has a great story worth hearing so make sure to strike up a conversation.

15.description: I would love to give this place a 3.5.  I really liked the small, cozy, funky vibe and the laid back atmosphere. The chicken my bf ordered was wonderful but the waffle fritters came in pancake form today, which wasn't as impressive.  I had the french toast which wasn't very flavorful.  If I ever came back, I would make sure I didn't have anything to do after because the wait for the food was extremely long.

57.description: If you're like me, you've driven or walked past this place assuming it was a run of the mill diner and thought nothing more. I'm so glad I finally decided to look into Grandma J's because it's nothing of the sort.It's super cozy and full of mix and match furniture and table settings. It's BYOB and they'll bring you and awesome Bloody Mary mix for you to pour your own vodka (they know the way to my heart). The food is definitely stellar. Bomb brunch.It's 4/5 only because I think it's slightly overpriced, but mostly because while the service was attentive, we felt like we were VERY rushed. There didn't happen to be a wait that day and I realize it's a tiny breakfast spot, but we were really looking forward to unwinding and enjoying the experience. I know it stinks when people linger and tables extensively, but by the time we left (it was about 45 minutes) I almost felt like we got kicked out.

20.description: Arrived here at 1pm, it's now 3 (closing time) and we have yet to be served. I've been here before, and they do have great food; however the wait time after you order is inexcusable.

36.description: SO good. This little gem is in the most unexpected spot but it is divine. Such friendly people serving the most delicious food. Unexpected deliciousness. You must go.

14.description: This place is a mecca for delicious food.We went on my bday brunch.  I have been stalking it on Yelp for awhile now.  It did not disappoint.Fried pickles...a bit soggy, but still goodB&G...might be the best I have ever had.  I am salivating thinking of them right nowFried chick sand...yummy!  Crispy chick with tender and juicy meat.  Some of the best bread I have had.The Works...it just worked.  AmazingnessThe staff are some of the nicest people.  I was shocked by the hospitality here.Super cute homey, place.  Go, eat, this place cant be beat.

12.description: My wife is from the Dominican Republic and we go here once in awhile for Dominican food when she does not feel like cooking.  The family is Dominican and the food is Dominican so this is the real deal.  The only problem is that you feel like your not welcome.  The owners treat other guests who come in that are Dominican friendly but if your borned in the United States its the cold shoulder and you sense that they don't like you.  Its like your being intrusive or your invading there neighborhood.  So the food is good and this place is legit but if your an American citizen borned in this country prepare to be made feel unwelcome and unwanted in your own country.  Bon Appetit!

7.description: Delicious & healthy portions! There's a restaurant in Wash Heights (ny) Nueva Espana that I like better but this place is amazing! Ordered takeout for 2 . The chicken soup, arroz con habichuelas, maduros and a half chicken. The white rice is free. The total came to less than $18 and could've served 4 people! There were leftovers & even 2 dogs were happy :) The only bummer is that they only serve sancocho on Sun:(

20.description: I give Tropical Taste 4 stars for heart. Being the only Dominican restaurant in Chicago for a long time (on and off, there is another one now) takes guts. However, the food is not so hot. There was a bodeguita on Fullerton that sold MUCH better Dominican food, but sadly, no longer there. But, if you're hankering for some pica pollo or a morro or some plain old arroz con habichuelas (bean girl!), this will do. However, if you want some slightly more expensive, but much better food, let me know and I'll give you the out-of-business bodeguita owner who sells REALLY good food out of her home.

19.description: I give Tropical Taste 4 stars for heart. Being the only Dominican restaurant in Chicago for a long time (on and off, there is another one now) takes guts. However, the food is not so hot. There was a bodeguita on Fullerton that sold MUCH better Dominican food, but sadly, no longer there. But, if you're hankering for some pica pollo or a morro or some plain old arroz con habichuelas (bean girl!), this will do. However, if you want some slightly more expensive, but much better food, let me know and I'll give you the out-of-business bodeguita owner who sells REALLY good food out of her home.

1.description: This is one of two Dominican places in Chicago. It is a shame because although the food is good the service is absolutely terrible. The owner is rude and nasty. The place is still open because the food is decent, otherwise if it depended on customer service it would have closed a while ago. In addition to the fact the the owner keeps the waitresses' tips if you pay with your credit card. We would visit this place quite often from work, but we will not be back. Spend your money elsewhere, trust me you will be glad you did.

2.description: At a site visit in the area, and a staff member recommended this Dominican place as an alternative to Puerto Rican food.  He told us, "it's a little whole in the wall kind of place" and he was not kidding. It's a very unassuming, small yet homey little restaurant.  NOTHING fancy about it, but as soon as we sat down the lady in charge came to take our orders and was very patient in explaining the menu to us. I ordered the beef stew (guisado de res) with white rice and beans, and my coworker ordered the 1/4 chicken with arroz con gandules.  As we sat and waited for our food, the same lady brought out a plate of fried chicken for another table.  My coworker then asked if he could order that instead, she informed us that that plate was the last one. My silly coworker asked if he could have a taste, and since she knew the other guests well asked for a drumstick for my coworker.  My coworker LOVED the fried chicken.  Then our food arrived and it was HEAVENLY, all of it!  We finished our meal with an order of maduros and another of tostones.  Those were amazing and perfect as well. Will be going back as soon as I can!

9.description: Very authentic Dominican food. You don't come here for the décor.

6.description: I'll give Tropical Taste a solid three stars for the meal I had there (stewed goat and rice with gandules) but really...the rest of the place probably deserves just two. The atmosphere is essentially that of a low-grade, slightly dirty, Chinese takeout place (i.e. none), and unless you speak Spanish you won't have much, if any, luck in communicating with the staff. Everyone working there the day I visited was friendly, but it was abundantly clear that many menu items were available that simply were not on the menu I was given, and nobody could communicate those options to me. Too bad.While the prices aren't bad, I'm not sure I'd call this a bargain either, at least when lunch runs over $10 if you order a drink and leave a tip. I'm not sure I would avoid this place, but the owners certainly don't do much to encourage repeat business either. There are several other nearby spots that offer much better food, service, and value. I'll probably search for Dominican food elsewhere in the future.

18.description: Now how in the hell is it that I live in Humboldt Park, and can't find a Puerto Rican restaurant that knows how to make arroz con gandules aka Puerto Rican rice, the RIGHT WAY?????  For the RIGHT price? (don't forget the rotisserie chicken) AND enough to feed my 250lbs ass for lunch AND dinner on one serving. I step into this hole in the wall Dominican joint and the lady already knows what I want. ...I'm hooked

10.description: I got lucky and enjoyed my food but not so for others in my group. I labored whether to go three or 2 stars but since I haven't had the desire to go back, I chose two.This place seems to have a very local vibe to it and unless you mesh right, the experience won't feel entirely welcoming. We came with a big group and instead of trying to win us over with service they lost us entirely.

13.description: This restaurant is a great value for your money, and as a Dominican I can tell you is authentic Dominican food!Dont expect a fancy restaurant here....its more of a cafeteria! food is seating there until its over, so the earlier the fresher.

16.description: Went last week and I am a fan of this restaurant! I moved here a few months ago and being Dominican I was craving good dominican food - I can confidently say this is good Dominican food : ) It has a very limited menu and is a hole in the wall, but it delivers the flavors that are dead on Dominican (a good thing)- well seasoned, flavorful, juicy meat. My favorite thing to get is the roasted chicken with the steamed yucca topped with grilled onions...tastes like my mom or grandma made it! Yum... Looking forward to trying a couple more of their dishes! Also the cost is very low for all they give you and the staff/owner is nice. I am giving this place 5 stars because it is good, authentic food - so if that's what you want, come here!  But don't come for the atmosphere. Also, I agree with the reviewer that said the food will be fresher when you go during peak times- lunch I assume would be the busiest...

17.description: As some of the other Yelpers mentioned... don't expect anything fancy and feels a little dirty... But, it's the real deal if you're looking for Dominican food in Chicago, it's cheap, and they give you a lot of food.

15.description: Typical delicious Dominican food. Don't expect anything fancy or exceptional service, just great portions, delicious food and a whole lot of dominicans!

0.description: Delicious! I don't have much of a reference point as it was my first time eating at a Dominican restaurant, but we really enjoyed it.We just ordered a bunch of things and shared them which is probably the way to go. The menu is quite limited, but clearly they know what they're doing.  The Mangu was my favorite and I absolutely loved the beans. We also had really good Tostones (although I'm used to having them with a sauce of some sort), chicken soup, yucca and roasted chicken all of which were good. I was not a big fan of the bacalao as it was over cooked and really fishy. Don't expect Americanized style service here either. Just because you know you are done eating does not mean they will just clear your plates and bring your check. You need to ask. Don't take this for bad service. It's just a cultural difference. Really loved the owner, she was very nice and very interested in our opinions of the food.Also of note, Carlos Marmol came in for lunch while we were there. Very cool and probably a great testament to the authenticity and quality here.

5.description: I did not know fear until I entered the darkened hall of Tropical Taste. Don't be fooled by the name: you won't be welcomed by calypso music and fruity beverages here. Instead, the groans of maligned guests will be your soundtrack and you'll sip the salty elixir of bitter tears.I arrived at this Humboldt Park spot because I hadn't eaten Dominican cuisine since I roamed the streets of Washington Heights in NYC. Searching around on the site, I came across a few options here in Chicago. Searching around on foot, I decided on Tropical Taste. You know the phrase, "Feets don't fail me now?" My feets? They failed me.What looks warm and inviting from the street is anything but on the inside. I'm not talking furniture or decor. I am talking about the rude ways in which the owner/cook/bodyguard/whoeversheis treating my party and in particular, me. I walked in, smiled and went about being my charming, adorable self. I was addressed in Spanish, I replied that I didn't speak Spanish (in Spanish) and the fun began. We were yelled at -- from the counter -- to give our orders within minutes of sitting down. Other tables were waited on. We were given a small selection of dishes from which to order. Other tables were given special menus and secret sauces (seriously). We were given food that may or not have been sitting around for a while. Other tables were given food so hot we saw steam rise from it. In particular, I ordered a fish dish with coconut milk. I was given (almost immediately after ordering) a cold fish dish with coconut milk. Cold. Fish. That had been cooked. Our tostones? No sauce. And dry. Very. Very. Very. Dry. I looked up at the counter (and at our antagonist) to inquire about wth was going on and received a "QUE?!" barked like from the mouth of a rabid pelican. Toucan. Rabid toucan.Basically, I was made to feel as though if I didn't speak Spanish, I was not welcome to be here. Fine. Cool. I get it. You want a certain clientele and that's it. Free country. Do you. The thing is, don't take my money. Don't open for business to the public. Get a dinner club license or something. Open to those on a mailing list. Y'see, if you're open to the public and take everyone's money, odds are you're going to get the occasional (or, every day ) guy or gal who doesn't speak your native tongue. But, there is a universal language: kindness. Smile. Point. Nod. Communicate in ways other than glares, loud sighs and sucked teeth. You lost a great opportunity to open your business to a new audience by being so needlessly hostile to a bunch of folks WHO GAVE YOU MONEY! But, I don't think you much care.oh, thatsecondstarisbecauseiamtooafraidofyoutogiveyout­heoneyoudeserve.

11.description: When you say 'tropical' you automatically think: sunny...warm...paradise...lively....welcoming....coconut......bikinis...wet swimming trunks...exposed abs....Okay, maybe not all this. I am fantasizing a little bit here. Hey, winter is slowly coming along so let me dream on...But here the taste left in your mouth after your meal is not that tropical. Read warm, sunny, welcoming and so on. Except that coconut can indeed lingers on your tongue if, like me, you opted for fish in coconut sauce for lunch. Seriously - this place was borderline rude to us. Fine, we were not all Dominican (but we had ONE among us!!!! Does it count for nothing?!?!?) but we were all polite, happy to be there and willing to order in Spanish. Because forget about Shakespeare here; and it's fine. Just be patient and understanding ladies por favor. I mean - we are giving you business after all. Be nice to us, yes?End result: my fish was lukewarm (at best), the goat stew was really bony and extra fatty, the maduros and tostones - dry and served sin salsa. So, so, so sad - I could have sung the blues would it have been culturally appropriate; but I was too worried to be shot by the pistols eyes of our hosts who wanted us out there so badly we could sense the bad vibrations all across the room.Oh, atmosphere........I got up to ask 'para la cuenta' (the others didn't dare) and we clearly saw that on other tables things look MUCH better: condiments, presentation, specials.....we were not on the right side of the Dom' Rep'.A shame? I would say so.Tropical Fail.

8.description: **UPDATE BELOW**This is the best Dominican food I've had in Chicago. I went to some place on Kimball not too far away from here and the food was HORRRIBLE. The morir sonando here is amazing. If you looking for something delicious that's Dominican and authentic you need look no further.UPDATE 3/23/2013I brought my mom here because my husband and I loved this place out first time. The second time WAS NOT a charm. Our waitress was all of 14 years old and she knew nothing of customer service. I'm sure it's because her mother has her being there working for free instead of hiring someone to come and actually give service. We got the pescado frito and the fish was dry, the lime they gave us doesn't help with the dryness. I ordered my mother pollo guisado and the pollo(chicken) was very chewy like jerky. No I'm black and my husband is Dominican so they assume neither of us speak Spanish because my husband looks like he's Filipino. The woman behind the counter said in Spanish to the 14yr old waitress "That's how its suppose to taste" I cook pollo guisado and many other Dominican dishes for my husband and it never tastes like that. I didn't even taste to cumin which is usually in guisado. My husband asked if the guisado could be taken off of the bill since no one is going to eat it and the lady behind the counter said NO. Now what kind of service is that!? After all that my mother still left a 5 dollar tip and they didn't even say thank you!! So in all, I don't see myself going back here.

3.description: The food was good. I ordered Moro de guandules which is yellow rice with pigeon peas and a side or morir soñando which is like a liquid creamsicle and it was pretty damn spot on with what I expected. I am giving them 3 instead of 4 stars because the service was super slow and while I've come to expect super slow service from Dominican restaurants based on my experience in DR and living

14.description: Food is good  . If your looking for inexpensive authntic dominican food this is the place to come.

4.description: Amazing oxtail stew.  The place is a real dive, and the chef speaks a bit of English, but the food is authentic.

3.description: As newlyweds, my husband and I happened to pass by The Humboldt House while walking my dog. Prior to that, we had been working closely with an interior decorator and other vendors, feeling quite confident in our vision of our home.My husband looked through the window of The Humboldt House and was immediately impressed. Claire, the owner, welcomed us in (dog and all) to see the store. To say the least, Claire's taste is excellent. She retrieves gorgeous vintage items and re-purposes them into beautiful statement pieces. On a personal level, she listened to us carefully while we described our dream decor, subsequently offering to let us explore at our own pace.We found a gorgeous vinyl couch (which was one of the pieces that  had immediately caught my husband's eye) and were instantly enamored. Claire encouraged us to sit in on the couch in order to make an informed decision. (She even served us beverages, alcoholic and non-, to ensure that we would be replicating our "real lives" on the couch). We ultimately ended up buying a complete living room set with the entirety of our wedding money.The twist in the story is that my husband and I shipped the vinyl couch home only to discover that there was a spot that was damaged beyond repair (due to a cleaning liquid spill that had preceded Claire's purchase). Claire generously referred us to a leather/vinyl expert, who provided us with thorough information about our couch and the material. When my husband and I learned that our couch would not endure a lifetime, Claire immediately offered to exchange the piece ($2400 store credit) with one that would meet our needs. Claire was extraordinarily accommodating, professional, and honest - making it clear that her interest was in our satisfaction - not in her financial gainBOTTOM LINE: The reason I am writing this review is because, if you are thinking of going to Restoration Hardware - THINK AGAIN! You will never receive the kind of personal, caring, and responsive customer service that you will get from Claire and her staff at The Humboldt House. It is clear that she is passionate about her craft, and eager to share beautiful pieces with those of us who would have succumbed to Ethan Allen, otherwise. Thank you, Claire, for making our dream home come true.

1.description: When I lived in DC, I used to date a guy who was obsessed with midcentury modern and was close friends with a guy who owned two stores specializing in MCM, so I learned a thing or two from their bro sessions.I know Claire sells the good stuff for a lot cheaper than other midcentury modern shops. The same names in great condition, just a different neighborhood. People who compare HH's furniture to what's in a Brown Elephant don't know what they're talking about. I got a Poul Hundevad storage unit (teak, made in Denmark) and a patchwork P.S. Heggen desk (teak, made in Norway, dude designed wastebaskets that now cost a fortune) on sale and delivered later that day at a reasonable price. Claire rules.

2.description: Definitely my favorite home goods store, and a welcome addition to the blossoming California/Augusta retail enclave.  There's a dearth of truly excellent shopping in Chicago, I wish we had more places like this.The space itself is very cozy and has a pleasant "domestic" feel to it, despite being on the ground floor of a recently constructed building.  In addition to really unique vintage furniture, they stock a ton of locally-made jewelry, candles, soaps, etc...if there's something or someone in my household that smells good, you have Humboldt House to thank.  Claire (the owner) and Chelsea are always very helpful, and have great taste; sometimes I have trouble making these crucial shopping decisions, and these two have never steered me wrong.I just moved into a larger apartment recently, and can't wait to pick up some decor (maybe some textiles?) for the new space.  Humboldt House is an inspiration, and will surely influence my decorating decisions in the future.

9.description: I had really high hopes for Humboldt House. I follow them on Instagram, and I regularly check out their site. I purchase mid-century furniture from several other retailers in Chicago, and I've been on the look out for tapestries, rugs, trinkets, and side tables. I didn't buy anything? Why the quality did not match the price? Some of pieces you could easily fine at the Brown Elephant for 80% off of what Humboldt House charges. The past two reviewers rave about the price, but as a frequent buyer, I'm not going to sacrifice quality for price. Other places in Chicago offer the same price for items that are 200x better quality. The place has a musty smell, which leads me to believe that the owner is not treating and taking care of the linens/tapestries that she's bringing in.  The place also could use a merchandising refresh...lots of holes in the wall, no order or reason to presentation. It looked like the owner just threw some things around. On top of the quality and presentation, I was very disappointed with the customer service. I drove Humboldt House on a Sunday, when I walked in the woman did not greet us or say anything. I was there for about 15 minutes, going back and forth looking at merchandise. Not once did she offer to help us or even suggest that maybe she had something that wasn't shown.

10.description: I found this place last year while riding my bike and knew I had to visit. I am always on the hunt for mid century modern furniture and have collected quite a bit because of this store. The owner (Hi Claire!) is super friendly, welcoming, knowledgeable, and is full of great ideas.  The shop is always so well put together and there's a constant influx of new items every time I go in! It's also next to a great pierogi shop and is pet friendly.

4.description: The vintage glasses were interesting and some of them were reasonably priced. I enjoyed seeing the mid century furniture- it seemed to be in good shape. And was fun to recall when stereoes lived on the wall, not in your pocket.The store can be difficult to move around in with narrow aisles. This was made all the more difficult by some sort of hipster dog photo shoot happening in the store while I was there. I know that sounds odd but no other description fits the goings on. I think because of bearded skinny jean photo nuts, we were not acknowledged by the staff at all during our  15 minute visit.

6.description: So many great things to see in this quaint little shop in Humboldt Park! Perfectly curated and lots of attention to detail. Maybe one of a kind items to be had.

12.description: What an awesome design and home goods spot- a great addition to the neighborhood, and it's right next to the best gardening shop and nursery ever, Adam & Son. You can fill your space with that many more beautiful and affordable treats at once :)  Claire and her dog are just lovely- I really appreciate that the ambiance and the items are so chic and upscale, while the prices are extremely reasonable- most other home design places with similar-looking things are easily triple the price. When I mentioned to Claire I had recently broken a new picture frame, she gave me a picture frame, some books and some other items she was planning to recycle- really sweet and generous of her. I definitely plan on coming back and adding some of her beautiful designs to my home.

5.description: Wow, wow, wow! What a great lil' neighborhood shop!Items priced from just $5.00 (Laura Berger cards - so cute!) to super swanky Turkish Kilim rugs - there's definitely a little somethin' somethin' for everyone.I have my eye on a couple of awesome mid century pieces as well as jewelry/wall hangings. Did I mention a majority of the goods are made by local artisans? Pretty nifty if ya ask me!HH is forever dynamic and forever cute. Do yourself a favor and visit ASAP.

13.description: What a gem! Beautiful vintage furniture, gorgeous textiles, thoughtfully selected housewares and treasures, all at extremely reasonable prices. Owner Claire is warm and friendly and shopdog Archie is just the cutest. Don't miss this lovely little shop if you're near Humboldt Park!

11.description: Humboldt House is such a wonderful addition to California Avenue.  The products, big and small, or unique and beautifully presented.  One of my favorite things about HH is all the goods created by local makers and artisans.  Humboldt House is a great place to shop for yourself or others.

8.description: Nice eclectic mix of jewelry from local artisans and vintage goods. Owner is a sweetheart and very knowledgeable about her merchandise and the local vintage scene.

0.description: After a couple of visits, I totally have Humboldt House on my radar for future gifts.  Other than the bigger home decor options like rugs and furniture and wall art, HH is also a great place to find locally made products by local artisans. The jewelry and ceramics I had my eye are very simple yet have a nice clean aesthetic to them. The soap stones look like large jewels and would make a really lovely presentation on any bathroom counter.  The candles--now those are my favorites.  I had never heard of Tatine until I saw them on HH's instagram feed and now are a new fave of mine.  The scents are really clean and their names are quite cute and irresistible  "Love that Burns"  "Swarm of Bees", etc. My eye caught a selection of cute cards/stationery.  I make my own cards so it has to be a really creative/eclectic design for me to even consider purchasing it, and the cards here are also also one of a kind. The owner Claire is super sweet and has done a great job putting together a store full of lovely finds and hand crafted objects.  I love this little corridor of California Avenue. HH is a great stop.

7.description: Adorable!  They have really great, well-priced items here.  Its a great location - as before mentioned by Adams & Sons.Very nice people, cool stuff, totally worth checking out!

1.description: I hired Kolin Group to remodel an unfinished basement for me. I could not be happier with the results. Michael and the guys did a great job for a very reasonable price. I'd highly recommend this company to anyone looking to do a remodel.

2.description: I used Michael and the Kolin Group to paint my one bedroom apartment back to its original color prior to moving out. Michael was great to work with throughout the entire process! He was prompt in his response when I reached out for an initial quote and he quickly provided me with a fair estimate.  He kept me updated through every step of the way on the project and the end result was excellent.   I would highly recommend working with them!

0.description: Like most, I rarely write reviews online unless my experience is really bad or really good. Luckily, working with Kolin Group and Mike himself was fantastic. I recently bought a house and to my surprise, discovered that the whole basement / garden level needed a major repair and remodeling done (something that wasn't even caught by the inspector before my purchase). So being under a lot of stress already, I've asked friends and searched online not simply for a highly rated reliable construction company, but for someone who would answer all my questions and oversee the process from the beginning til the end. I selected Kolin Group because out of few places I called for an estimate, Mike was the first one to respond, the first one to come by for an assessment and besides giving me a great price, he really spent a good amount of time explaining me why the moist problem like the one I had occurs, how it affects the flooring, and what he would do to prevent it and to completely re-do the walls and floor. I really liked such attention and thorough explanation.   So Mike and his workers did do everything the way I wanted. They called me will all the updates on remodeling, suggested various options and ways of doing the floor and other wooden elements. All the workers were professional and knowledgeable, too. Not to mention that the communication with these guys was a breeze. From the floors to re-done walls to even a painting job - basement looks top notch now.I am super happy with the job they have done and an overall experience I've had with them. Will most likely be calling Kolin Group again in the spring to re-do my deck. Cheers.

1.description: I've gone here 2 times for Mani n pedi. Hubby bought me a gift certificate once, and 2nd time was becuase I was around the area, and it was convenient to go here before my next errand. Not the greatest experience both times. Little scary with their cleanliness. Attitude quite big here... More like rude and arrogant.I only go to do my eyebrows. I'll tolerate a revisit just for eyebrows. Only place that makes them look fabulous and it's only $7. That's what the star is for- only one thing ok here.

2.description: This place is  totally unclean actually dirty and they are not  professional at all there is a  never ending parade of  bootleg purses,socks,DVD's  seller's going in and out all the time.A couple people  do good nails here and they are cheap my only reason for returning .They have an overly rude way of treating patrons,,more like kids trying to be  kool.Never saw so many backroom & smoke breaks during business. They also have a dollar service charge  for  using a credit or debit card wow!!Their pedicures are no better than me polishing my own toes,did that once never again.

0.description: The service in this establishment is terrible !! They aren't organized they have no order. They are not professional .. The west side of Chicago has a lot to offer but unfortunately Lee's nails isn't one of them .

28.description: We went last evening and were treated to delicious oysters and shrimp cocktail for first courses. For our main we chose a monkfish which was perfectly prepared in a bed of spinach and lemon sauce. Even the cocktails were well done as the Aviation is served with red maraschino cherries that give perfect balance to the gin. For dessert, we had the brioche rum caked with cherries and cream. Absolutely outstanding! We will be going back.

1.description: Price point is a bit high on some items. The two things we tasted were delicious. The confusing menus must change. In this day and age of printing in house, cheep ass paper and single terminology will get you know where. 6 pages of menu items, yet a sandwich is described as HMBLT????? WTF, not only can you not describe the sandwich, you can't even offer up the entire spelling.....The Humboldt, turns out to be a decadent version of a BLT featuring Herring mayonnaise, it was great.Caviar $9??? Just caviar? On toast? Ok thanks, yes its on toast, I am then told in a snarky manner, the hash browns are not on toast, thanks buddy, I get it now, all items are ala cart with a side of snide. I will return, I have high hopes for the quality, but right now they need serious direction.

9.description: Wonderful service, quality food, and bright atmosphere.

29.description: They've just opened, and I've already gone twice... that is how much I liked it. I went with several friends and it was recommended to share. I don't like to share, but I wanted to sample as much off the menu as I could. Price isn't cheap, but the quality of ingredients (farm to table) is very high. You get what you pay for.  1. The 1/2 sandwich (ham and gruyere) and bean soup w/ pork was excellent combo for Chicago in the winter. 2. My friend ordered the new potatoes and slapped my hand for eating too many of them. Fried and salty, so good. I probably shouldn't know what they are fried in.3. My co-pilot ordered the roasted squash and hazel nuts, very good.4. Homemade English Muffins, amazing!5. Off Color Brewing has become one of my fav. local breweries, and at 2 miles away, you can't get more local than them. Only Con: is that they hadn't built out the grab-n-go section. I think the idea is to get farm to table meats, eggs, cheese, milk, etc. I look forward to see how that plays out.

23.description: Great to have a place cooking high quality french inspired food.  Loved the cocktails, tartare, and champagne mushrooms.  Very friendly service.  Looking forward to trying more items from their menu.Brunch looks good as well.

5.description: Just had a crazy feast of a dinner here and beyond impressed.Oysters, olives, veggies and dip, smoked fish plate, half chicken, mushrooms, acorn squash, and red snapper special paired w wine, beers, and cocktails. For a first time visit, I think we nailed it and really, Cafe Marie Jeanne nailed it.Oysters - these were described as deep water oysters that were larger than average and were fresh, well shucked and served with horseradish, cocktail sauce and mignonette.Olives - large serving with tasty olive oil at the bottom, maybe castelvetranos but unsure.Veggies and onion dip - awesome mix of carrots, radish, endive and apples w good dip. Veggies were the star.Smoked fish plate was BOMB. 5 different fish varieties served w awesome bread, cream cheese and capers. Hot damn, best smoked fish plate I've ever had.Half chicken- holy mother of god. This was mind blowing, the chicken tasted like a ham and was perfectly prepared. Best chicken dish in the city imo.Snapper special- served whole and was amazing. I wish it was permanently on the menu. Mushroom and acorn squash sides were good but not especially memorable against all these other stand outs.I'm quite impressed w the meal we had and hope this restaurant becomes a long time staple like rootstock, which I heard is where the chef owners came from.Bravo!

31.description: Visited this place this past weekend - very happy to see something take the place of the beloved Knockbox, as that place is missed greatly. I have high hopes for this spot, but think they still have some work to do. The place needs some artwork up on the walls, and perhaps even more seating - it feels pretty sparse and cold in there still, but I assume (hope) that with some more touches that will come. I believe it was described originally as also having a deli section for take out items, so I was disappointed to see that that section really just consisted of a couple types of meat. The menu is fairly pricey; I was unprepared to pay $17 for two coffee drinks and a pastry. Coffee was good, the pastry was mediocre. Menu looked interesting, (though I would appreciate descriptions of the menu items, as there currently are none), and I'll definitely be back to try a meal there. The staff seemed a bit frazzled, which is understandable for having just opened, but were quite friendly. I'm sure that the owners will eventually bring this place together and it will evolve into a great neighborhood spot.

25.description: I have been waiting for this place to open for months, and I couldn't be happier. For all of you Yelpers hung up on price, the price point for this restaurant is perfect. Everything is made in house and quality ingredients and labor come at a price. If you want cheap, Mcdonalds serves breakfast all day now. If you want incredible food served by people obsessed with quality, become a regular.

12.description: Went for breakfast on a Saturday. It's definitely inviting, though sitting in the front of the cafe is less desirable to the coziness of the back. While I was really looking forward to a new breakfast and lunch spot in the neighborhood, I was pretty disappointed with our first visit.1. The a la carte menu is expensive. Waaaay expensive. And I'll pay for a lot of money for good food, but the bill really struck me as excessive for what I got. I guess I was charged extra for the dismissive attitude of the hostess. 2. The eggs I ordered were super gross. I'm guessing they were going for the Chef Ludo style French scrambled eggs, and they got the color right, but damn, these were the greasiest eggs I've ever had. And not like, buttery tasty greasy, but like industrial-lube greasy. 3. One of my a la carte choices was toast and jam. Three dollar toast and jam. The options were a tomato jam and an apple butter. I got two paper-thin slices of day old bread and a thimble of apple sauce. I had to beg the bus boy for butter. 4. Our waitress disappeared. There were three servers and a counter person for 5 tables, and our waitress never came back to give us coffee or salt (which was sorely needed) or to even see if we needed to order more items to supplement a truly stingy meal. I regret not palming the busboy a tip because he was basically our waiter. I was going to give this place 2 stars instead of 1 because the coffee was decent and it just opened so I wanted to allow for space to improve, but then I remembered just how inhospitable our hostess was and I went back to 1 star. I can forgive a lot if the staff is genuine and friendly, but that is clearly not the case here. For now I'm sticking to Haywood and Feed and Dark Matter and the Flying Saucer and Spinning J and CC Ferns.

21.description: Great new spot on the exploding corner of Augusta and California. Menu is really interesting (the steak tartare was great and the chicken comes highly recommended). Good cocktail and wine list, and the bartender on my visit was truly an inspiration. I'm looking forward to going back for brunch, lunch, and more drinks in the future.

16.description: I easily find myself spending most of my week there. Breakfast lunch and dinner, all the best. The new neighborhood spot. I highly suggest checking it out! The bread rules.

17.description: Damn fine.  Slinging some of the best sausage and hash browns around, and who's gonna argue with cheesy broccoli. The Griddler (flapjacks, sausage, eggs, cheese, stacked) hurts so good.  It was like it was having drunk, alley sex with my arteries.  Dope service, strong coffee, and the chef is muy dreamy.

10.description: Went for breakfast today and really enjoyed the food, service and atmosphere!  Good eggs, bacon, cheesy broccoli, and latte.

11.description: I've had a few nice times at this new spot. The smoked chicken is awesome and I highly recommend it, especially for $10. The veggie pot pie is also really good, even for a meat eater like myself. Great selection of wine and the beer options are growing. I've had the french onion a couple times and its tasty. Servers and bartenders have always been really friendly and knowledgeable. I'm looking forward to seeing what they do to the place over this year and will update my reviews.

26.description: Damn fine.  Slinging some of the best sausage and hash browns around, and who's gonna argue with cheesy broccoli. The Griddler (flapjacks, sausage, eggs, cheese, stacked) hurts so good.  It was like it was having drunk, alley sex with my arteries.  Dope service, strong coffee, and the chef is muy dreamy.

27.description: Went for breakfast on a Saturday. It's definitely inviting, though sitting in the front of the cafe is less desirable to the coziness of the back. While I was really looking forward to a new breakfast and lunch spot in the neighborhood, I was pretty disappointed with our first visit.1. The a la carte menu is expensive. Waaaay expensive. And I'll pay for a lot of money for good food, but the bill really struck me as excessive for what I got. I guess I was charged extra for the dismissive attitude of the hostess. 2. The eggs I ordered were super gross. I'm guessing they were going for the Chef Ludo style French scrambled eggs, and they got the color right, but damn, these were the greasiest eggs I've ever had. And not like, buttery tasty greasy, but like industrial-lube greasy. 3. One of my a la carte choices was toast and jam. Three dollar toast and jam. The options were a tomato jam and an apple butter. I got two paper-thin slices of day old bread and a thimble of apple sauce. I had to beg the bus boy for butter. 4. Our waitress disappeared. There were three servers and a counter person for 5 tables, and our waitress never came back to give us coffee or salt (which was sorely needed) or to even see if we needed to order more items to supplement a truly stingy meal. I regret not palming the busboy a tip because he was basically our waiter. I was going to give this place 2 stars instead of 1 because the coffee was decent and it just opened so I wanted to allow for space to improve, but then I remembered just how inhospitable our hostess was and I went back to 1 star. I can forgive a lot if the staff is genuine and friendly, but that is clearly not the case here. For now I'm sticking to Haywood and Feed and Dark Matter and the Flying Saucer and Spinning J and CC Ferns.

35.description: I went today and it was a miserable experience from beginning to end.  I am sorry that this place exists and feel bad that I spent money there.  I was made to feel unwanted, stupid and a burden.  To start they make ordering food very hard, the menu is not only not customer friendly but also not server friendly.  By writing food in a foreign language, then not describing it and using vague terms for the food items in English I am forced to ask the server multiple questions and wait for answers.  This is especially frustrating when everything is al carte; it takes forever to figure out the most basic order.  Also why in the world would you bring a whole table coffee but no sugar or cream and then act put out when it's requested? It's not surprising that they had issues filling the order, that it arrived cold and I was still hungry but didn't want to order anything else because of the high prices/small portions and that I'd have to wait forever for it.  This horrible menu system also makes it no surprise that food orders arrived wrong.  What was surprising was that the server's response was aggressive, accusing and generally insulting.  What you brought out wasn't what was ordered, was gross and frankly you shouldn't speak to customers like that.On a whole the experience was a sad and depressing evolution of the neighborhood.  I was made to feel uncomfortable and I'm their ideal customer- a white, educated individual that has disposable income to spend on food by eating out more than I should.   I was sitting with a group of well-traveled individuals that could understand most of the menu and they were also made to feel less than.  I can't imagine what it would feel like to be any of my neighbors; lower income people of color that have lived here for years.  If I was made to feel small and unwanted in this establishment I can only imagine how damaging a dining experience here would be for them.  This place is not meant for them, or me.  It sends a clear message; move out already, we don't want you here.  This place is for the new people we hope move here.  It's even more depressing when you reflect that a friendly neighborhood coffee shop was kicked out to make way for this pretentious hipster haven.

8.description: Nice place. Chill environment. I live nearby and picked up a smoked chicken sandwich. I was a bit disheartened by the $7 price tag for half of a sandwich, but it was pretty damn good. Bread was toasted I found it to be a bit too hard - crunchy almost - but the chIcken was amazing. A bit expensive for me to eat regularly but I definitely want to go back at some point.I thought the sandwich was really good but I only give 4/5 because of the price. I can get a great hearty burger for the same price across the street, so it depends how much a sandwich is worth it for you.

0.description: Casual environment, Great Service, Awesome Food.I will definitely be back.  I came for breakfast and when I arrived it was not too busy.  By the time I left, the place was pretty packed.  I liked that the breakfast options had a bunch of a la carte options to build your customized plate off of.  The bread/toast here is home baked, very crusty on the outside, nice and chew on the inside.  Their jam was delicious and has whole pieces of fruit in it and I was surprised to hear they don't make it in-house.  Probably smart though that they don't!The smoked pecan french toast is one of the best french toast dishes I have had.  Not too sweet, nice and custardy.The wife enjoyed her Croque Madame and said it was one of the best versions of the dish she has ever had.I saw the veggie dagwood on the lunch menu.  The waitress kindly checked whether the kitchen could make me one to go.  It was tasty and I would come back just for that sandwich again!

20.description: I easily find myself spending most of my week there. Breakfast lunch and dinner, all the best. The new neighborhood spot. I highly suggest checking it out! The bread rules.

19.description: Coffee is $3.50 before tax and tip.Food was pretty good.

33.description: I've had all around wonderful experiences at Café Marie-Jeanne.  On a cold, Chicago day it is a warm and welcoming place and the same can be said for the comforting food. I particularly enjoyed the apple and fennel salad with yogurt and hazel.  The praline monkey bread was delicate and delicious. Also not to be missed are the home fries. It's obvious that only quality, carefully selected ingredients are used.  I'm often overwhelmed by book-length drink menus, so I was happy to see a thoughtfully curated wine list. All of this made even more enjoyable by the excellent service, good music, and overall pleasant atmosphere. I look forward to many more meals at Café Marie-Jeanne.

2.description: I'm really hoping this place has a good run in this location. Actually the space has been occupied by some decent company from Humboldt Pie to Knockbox.The operator is the former EC of Rootstock and has totally got his shit together in industry knowledge and passion for supporting local and sustainable before it became (in this case, thankfully) trendy and fashionable.  Based on several visits thus far, i've no doubt CMJ will do just fine.

34.description: Really, really enjoyed our dinner last night. Wine menu was very nice, with some interesting and new to us selections. Everything we ordered from the dinner menu we did not regret! Started with some olives (unassuming appearance but interesting cure/pickling flavor that made them stand out more than normal), shared the romaine and bacon salad, which despite it having bacon still felt pretty light and really nice. For the main we got the half chicken with sweet potato side. Prepared to perfection, both of them. Chicken was moist and insanely delicious with crispy outer skin. This was set on top homemade bread and onions that were very good. The service staff we experienced were all very nice and helpful in explaining menu items. I feel like value matches the price point. I will definitely be back and really want to check out the breakfast menu, where it appears that in-house baked goods abound!

32.description: This place is new and just getting started, but already has a great ambiance and is a comfortable place to hang out and eat with friends. The à la carte style of the menu makes it easy to customize your meal. I had the brisket, which was excellent, but was able to try a number of other items, and they were all great. I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong with your order. Service was also excellent.

18.description: This place is fantastic.  Exactly what the neighborhood needs.  My hubby and I went there on Saturday for a breakfast date and we had a variety of items off the a la carte style menu.  It was perfect because it allowed us to try lots of different things. We tried a yogurt that had hazelnuts, green apple and fennel...such an interesting combo of flavor and textures.  It was so delicious.  Also tried something that starts with a "g" (can't remember the name), that was like homemade Nutella (but waaaay better) with delicious crusty bread.  To balance things out with some savory stuff, we had the pork chops with beans and a fried egg on top.  Stellar.  Also tried the baked sweet potato with sheeps milk cheese. This place is the real deal.  Go...now.

13.description: Great to have a place cooking high quality french inspired food.  Loved the cocktails, tartare, and champagne mushrooms.  Very friendly service.  Looking forward to trying more items from their menu.Brunch looks good as well.

4.description: Such a hidden gem. Came in on a Saturday at 10 am and there was NO wait. That was scary at first,  however,  the food is legit, the service is great, and it is a cool friendly environment. Smoked pecan French toast and prok jowl bacon were on point!

24.description: Just had a crazy feast of a dinner here and beyond impressed.Oysters, olives, veggies and dip, smoked fish plate, half chicken, mushrooms, acorn squash, and red snapper special paired w wine, beers, and cocktails. For a first time visit, I think we nailed it and really, Cafe Marie Jeanne nailed it.Oysters - these were described as deep water oysters that were larger than average and were fresh, well shucked and served with horseradish, cocktail sauce and mignonette.Olives - large serving with tasty olive oil at the bottom, maybe castelvetranos but unsure.Veggies and onion dip - awesome mix of carrots, radish, endive and apples w good dip. Veggies were the star.Smoked fish plate was BOMB. 5 different fish varieties served w awesome bread, cream cheese and capers. Hot damn, best smoked fish plate I've ever had.Half chicken- holy mother of god. This was mind blowing, the chicken tasted like a ham and was perfectly prepared. Best chicken dish in the city imo.Snapper special- served whole and was amazing. I wish it was permanently on the menu. Mushroom and acorn squash sides were good but not especially memorable against all these other stand outs.I'm quite impressed w the meal we had and hope this restaurant becomes a long time staple like rootstock, which I heard is where the chef owners came from.Bravo!

6.description: They've just opened, and I've already gone twice... that is how much I liked it. I went with several friends and it was recommended to share. I don't like to share, but I wanted to sample as much off the menu as I could. Price isn't cheap, but the quality of ingredients (farm to table) is very high. You get what you pay for.  1. The 1/2 sandwich (ham and gruyere) and bean soup w/ pork was excellent combo for Chicago in the winter. 2. My friend ordered the new potatoes and slapped my hand for eating too many of them. Fried and salty, so good. I probably shouldn't know what they are fried in.3. My co-pilot ordered the roasted squash and hazel nuts, very good.4. Homemade English Muffins, amazing!5. Off Color Brewing has become one of my fav. local breweries, and at 2 miles away, you can't get more local than them. Only Con: is that they hadn't built out the grab-n-go section. I think the idea is to get farm to table meats, eggs, cheese, milk, etc. I look forward to see how that plays out.

22.description: mmm. mmm. That was a tasty chicken dinner and a great value, too.  It's butchered perfectly for sharing or for just pounding it to completion. (as I did)  The bartender was great, and recommended some really unusual wines.  I also had the grilled endive, the ham and butter, and the potato side dish.  All great.  The ham melted in my mouth, and I'm sure they're putting those ham bones to good use in the soup if it's anything like the rest of the dishes I had.I look forward to going during the day to try their breakfast and to bring home a loaf of that delicious smelling bread.

15.description: I have been waiting for this place to open for months, and I couldn't be happier. For all of you Yelpers hung up on price, the price point for this restaurant is perfect. Everything is made in house and quality ingredients and labor come at a price. If you want cheap, Mcdonalds serves breakfast all day now. If you want incredible food served by people obsessed with quality, become a regular.

7.description: I've eaten here twice since it opened. Had the breakfast sandwich both times. I like being able to choose my own toppings. Quality is great. Good strong coffee and friendly staff. So nice to have a new option in the area.
